xxl.core.collections.containers
Interface Container

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractContainer, BlockFileContainer, BufferedContainer, ConstrainedDecoratorContainer, ConverterContainer, CounterContainer, DecoratorContainer, EmptyContainer, MapContainer, MultiBlockContainer, RawAccessContainer, RecordManager, SynchronizedContainer, UnmodifiableContainer, VerificationContainer
public interface Container

A Container is the interface implemented by all classes that deal with the management of sets of objects.

A Container represents a set of items, known as its elements. An element is a tuple consisting of an identifier id and an object. An object in a container can only be retrieved when the corresponding identifier is given. When inserting an object, or when reserving space for an object, the container creates a new id for this object and returns it to the caller. When an object is deleted from a container, its id can be reused again.

An iterator is frequently used to retrieve the ids of a container, see the method ids(). Moreover, a cursor is already implemented that supports the direct access to the objects, see the method objects(). When a collection is closed (see method close()) the iterators and cursors can be in illegal states. It might be that an iterator will still deliver data although the corresponding container is already closed.

When an element is directly deleted from a container via remove() or an element is inserted into a container via insert(), the iterators and cursors can be in an illegal state, see also the discussion in the previous paragraph. Note that iterators and cursors may also have an operation remove(). In particular, the remove() operation of an iterator should not rely on the remove() operation of Container. When remove() of an iterator is called, the iterator will still be in a valid state. HOWEVER, the other iterators of the corresponding container can be in illegal states. A similar problem occurs for updates. When a cursor updates an element of the container, the other iterators (and cursors) can be in illegal states. When a user of this class is interested in a more restrictive semantic, he/she is advised to implement the abstract methods ids() and objects() adequately. Note, that these are the only methods for generating iterators operating directly on a container.

Implementations of Container are available which manage the data in main memory (e.g. MapContainer) and external storage. The later case will be more common. In order to reduce the number of accesses to external memory, a buffer can be used to keep "interesting" data in main memory. This aspect has some impact on the Container class. Many of the methods below offer a parameter unfix. If true, the method automatically has to unfix the object at the end of the operation, i.e. an underlying buffer is allowed to remove the object from memory (probably having it written back to external memory before). Otherwise (unfix == false), the object will remain fixed, i.e. the object can only be removed from memory if the method unfix() has been called explicitly before. When a container uses a buffer, the method flush() has to be implemented. The method writes back the modified objects from the buffer to the container.

See Also:
AbstractContainer, Converter, Cursor, Cursors, FixedSizeConverter, Function, Iterator, Mapper, NoSuchElementException

Method Detail

clear

void clear()
Removes all elements from the Container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.

close

void close()
Closes the Container and releases all sources. For external containers, this method closes the files immediately. MOREOVER, all iterators operating on the container can be in illegal states. Close can be called a second time without any impact. Note, that it would be desirable that the finalize-mechanism of Java would already offer the functionality of close. However, finalize does not release the sources immediately! Consequently, the corresponding file of a "closed" Container may be opened and some of the data is still not written back. This is a problem when for example the JVM stops running (because of a system error).

contains

boolean contains(Object id)
Returns true if there is an object stored within the container having the identifier id.

Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
Returns:
true if the container contains an object for the specified identifier.

flush

void flush()
Flushes all modified elements from the buffer into the container. After this call the buffer and the container are synchronized.

flush

void flush(Object id)
Flushes the object with identifier id from the buffer into the container.

Parameters:
id - identifier of the object that should be written back.

get

Object get(Object id,
           boolean unfix)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown if there is not object stored with this id. If unfix is set to true, the object can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the object has to be kept in the buffer.

Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

get

Object get(Object id)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. It is equivalent to get(id, true).

Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

getAll

Iterator getAll(Iterator ids,
                boolean unfix)
                throws NoSuchElementException
Returns an iterator referring to the objects of the identifiers which are delivered by the iterator ids. The parameter unfix specifies whether the object can be removed from the buffer, see also the discussion of the method get().

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
unfix - signals whether the objects of the iterator can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
an iterator of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if one of the desired objects is not found.

getAll

Iterator getAll(Iterator ids)
                throws NoSuchElementException
Returns an iterator pointing to the Object of the given ids. It should behave like a call of getAll(ids, true).

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of object identifiers.
Returns:
an iterator of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if one of the desired objects is not found.

ids

Iterator ids()
Returns an iterator that delivers all the identifiers of the container that are in use.

Returns:
an iterator of all identifiers used by this container.

insert

Object insert(Object object,
              boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. The identifier can be reused again when the object is deleted from the container. If unfixed, the object can be removed from the buffer. Otherwise, it has to be kept in the buffer until an unfix() is called.
After an insertion all the iterators operating on the container can be in an invalid state.
This method also allows an insertion of a null object. In the application would really like to have such objects in the container, some methods have to be modified.

Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

insert

Object insert(Object object)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier. This methods should behave like insert(object, true).

Parameters:
object - is the new object.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

insertAll

Iterator insertAll(Iterator objects,
                   boolean unfix)
Inserts all objects of a given Iterator into the container. It returns an iterator that contains the identifiers of the new objects.
Note, that the order of the identifiers corresponds to the order of their objects. The meaning of unfix is the same as for the method insert.

Parameters:
objects - an iterator of objects that should be inserted.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
an iterator containing the identifiers of the objects of the input iterator.

insertAll

Iterator insertAll(Iterator objects)
Inserts all objects of a given Iterator into the container. This method should behave like insertAll(objects, true).

Parameters:
objects - an iterator of objects that should be inserted.
Returns:
an iterator containing the identifiers of the objects of the input iterator.

isUsed

boolean isUsed(Object id)
Checks whether the id has been returned previously by a call to insert or reserve and hasn't been removed so far.

Parameters:
id - the id to be checked.
Returns:
true exactly if the id is still in use.

objects

Cursor objects()
Returns a cursor containing all objects of the container. The order in which the cursor delivers the objects is not specified.

Returns:
a cursor containing all objects of the container.

objectIdConverter

FixedSizeConverter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Since the identifier may have an arbitrary type (which has to be known in the container), the container has to provide such a method when the data is not stored in main memory.

Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

getIdSize

int getIdSize()
Returns the size of the ids generated by this container in bytes. Each id must have the same size.

Returns:
the size in bytes of each id.

remove

void remove(Object id)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.
After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.

Parameters:
id - an identifier of an object.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

removeAll

void removeAll(Iterator ids)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Removes the objects with the identifiers given by the iterator ids.

Parameters:
ids - an iterator containing identifiers of objects.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids is not in the container.

reserve

Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject.

Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:
the reserved id.

size

int size()
Returns the number of elements of the container.

Returns:
the number of elements.

unfix

void unfix(Object id)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Unfixes the Object with identifier id. This method throws an exception when the identifier id isn't used by the container. After one call of unfix the buffer is allowed to remove the object (although the objects have been fixed more than once).

Parameters:
id - identifier of an object that should be unfixed in the buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the identifier id isn't used by the container.

unfixAll

void unfixAll(Iterator ids)
              throws NoSuchElementException
Unfixes the objects with identifiers given by iterator ids. All the objects are unfixed which belong to one of the identifiers of ids.

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the identifier id isn't used by the container.

update

void update(Object id,
            Object object,
            boolean unfix)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

update

void update(Object id,
            Object object)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

updateAll

void updateAll(Iterator ids,
               Function function,
               boolean unfix)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids.

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
function - a function that computes the object which should be associated to an identifier.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

void updateAll(Iterator ids,
               Function function)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. This method should be equivalent to updateAll(ids, function, true).

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers.
function - a function that computes the object which should be associated to an identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

void updateAll(Iterator ids,
               Iterator objects,
               boolean unfix)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. The objects that have to be associated to the elements are also given as an iterator.

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers
objects - an iterator of objects
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.

updateAll

void updateAll(Iterator ids,
               Iterator objects)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites the elements of a container whose identifiers are given by iterator ids. This method should be equivalent to updateAll(ids, objects, true).

Parameters:
ids - an iterator of identifiers
objects - an iterator of objects
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier of ids does not exist in the container.
